messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Data structures for Approximate Discrete FrÃ©chet distance

Paper Abstract: Abstract The FrÃ©chet distance is one of the most studied distance measures between curves Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q. The data structure variant of the problem is a longstanding open problem: Efficiently preprocess Pğ‘ƒP, so that for any Qğ‘„Q given at query time, one can efficiently approximate their FrÃ©chet distance. There exist conditional lower bounds that prohibit (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)-approximate FrÃ©chet distance computations in subquadratic time, even when preprocessing Pğ‘ƒP using any polynomial amount of time and space. As a consequence, the problem has been studied under various restrictions: restricting Qğ‘„Q to be a (horizontal) segment, or requiring Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q to be so-called realistic input curves. In this paper, we consider two types of realistic curves: cğ‘c-packed and Îºğœ…\kappa-straight curves for parameters cğ‘c and Îºğœ…\kappa which are curves that are respectively not too dense, or reasonably straight. We study FrÃ©chet distance computation in any metric space ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} between a realistic input curve Pğ‘ƒP and any query curve Qğ‘„Q. We give a data structure for (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)-approximate discrete FrÃ©chet distance in any metric space ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} between a realistic input curve Pğ‘ƒP and any query curve Qğ‘„Q. After preprocessing the input curve Pğ‘ƒP (with |P|=nğ‘ƒğ‘›|P|=n vertices) in Oâ€‹(nâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(n\log n) time, we may answer queries specifying a query curve Qğ‘„Q and an Îµğœ€\varepsilon, and output a value dâ€‹(P,Q)ğ‘‘ğ‘ƒğ‘„d(P,Q) which is at most a (1+Îµ)1ğœ€(1+\varepsilon)-factor away from the true FrÃ©chet distance between Qğ‘„Q and Pğ‘ƒP. Our query time is asymptotically linear in |Q|=mğ‘„ğ‘š|Q|=m, 1Îµ1ğœ€\frac{1}{\varepsilon}, logâ¡nğ‘›\log n, and the realism parameter cğ‘c or Îºğœ…\kappa. Our data structure allows us to append or reduce Pğ‘ƒP. We use randomized update algorithms that take Oâ€‹(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n) time per operation, with high probability. Our data structure is the first to: adapt to the approximation parameter Îµğœ€\varepsilon at query time, handle query curves with arbitrarily many vertices, work for any ambient space of the curves, or be dynamic. The method presented in this paper simplifies and generalizes previous contributions to the static problem variant. Particularly, we show how to go from approximately deciding the FrÃ©chet distance, to computing an approximate value without the typically-used Well Separated Pair Decomposition of (P,Q)ğ‘ƒğ‘„(P,Q), which has Oâ€‹(2dâ€‹n+dâ€‹nâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘›O(2^{d}n+dn\log n) construction time in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}, or parametric search, which, when applied to sublinear decision algorithms, commonly squares the decision time. We obtain subquadratic total running time in any metric space, including walks on planar graphs, geodesic distance spaces, and even â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} for d<nğ‘‘ğ‘›d<n. Our algorithm takes into account that one may not have oracle-access to exact distances in ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, assuming oracle-access to approximate distances for some parameterized query cost. We obtain efficient queries and static algorithms for FrÃ©chet distance computation in high-dimensional spaces and other metric spaces, e.g. when ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} is a graph under the shortest path metric, or the geodesic distance in a polygon.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Computing the discrete frÃ©chet distance in subquadratic time",
        "Computing the FrÃ©chet distance between two polygonal curves",
        "Comparison of distance measures for planar curves",
        "Efficient nearest-neighbor query and clustering of planar curves",
        "Strategic air traffic planning with FrÃ©chet distance aggregation and rerouting",

        "Why walking the dog takes time: FrÃ©chet distance has no strongly subquadratic algorithms unless SETH fails",
        "Improved approximation for FrÃ©chet distance on c-packed curves matching conditional lower bounds",
        "Approximability of the discrete FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Clustering trajectories for map construction",
        "Four soviets walk the dog: Improved bounds for computing the FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Seth says: Weak FrÃ©chet distance is faster, but only if it is continuous and in one dimension",
        "Group diagrams for representing trajectories",
        "Efficient FrÃ©chet distance queries for segments",
        "An improved approximation algorithm for the discrete FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Approximate map matching with respect to the frÃ©chet distance",
        "Fast frÃ©chet queries",
        "Data structures for FrÃ©chet queries in trajectory data",
        "A new merging process for data integration based on the discrete FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Jaywalking your dog: computing the FrÃ©chet distance with shortcuts",
        "Approximating the FrÃ©chet distance for realistic curves in near linear time",
        "(2+Ïµ)2italic-Ïµ(2+\\epsilon)-ANN for time series under the FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Sublinear data structures for short frÃ©chet queries",
        "On the FrÃ©chet distance in graphs",
        "Computing discrete FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Smoothing the gap between np and er",
        "Static and streaming data structures for frÃ©chet distance queries",
        "Approximate nearest neighbor for curves â€“ simple, efficient, and deterministic",
        "Universal approximate simplification under the discrete frÃ©chet distance",
        "Dynamic well-separated pair decomposition made easy",
        "Map matching queries on realistic input graphs under the frÃ©chet distance",
        "FrÃ©chet distance queries in trajectory data",
        "Optimal shortest path queries in a simple polygon",
        "Geometric approximation algorithms",
        "Protein structureâ€“structure alignment with discrete FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Visual analytics of delays and interaction in movement data",
        "Planar distance oracles with better time-space tradeoffs",
        "Coastline matching process based on the discrete FrÃ©chet distance",
        "Applying parallel computation algorithms in the design of serial algorithms",
        "Vehicle trajectory similarity: Models, methods, and applications",
        "FrÃ©chet distance based approach for searching online handwritten documents",
        "A survey of trajectory distance measures and performance evaluation",
        "Compact oracles for reachability and approximate distances in planar digraphs",
        "A subquadratic nÎµsuperscriptğ‘›ğœ€n^{\\varepsilon}-approximation for the continuous frÃ©chet distance",
        "Motion planning amidst fat obstacles",
        "Parametric search made practical",
        "Distributed trajectory similarity search",
        "Well-separated pair decompositions for doubling metric spaces"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Data structures for Approximate Discrete FrÃ©chet distance, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
